newsitem.title: USA: Pena plans meeting on U.S. nuclear waste lawsuit.
newsitem.headline: Pena plans meeting on U.S. nuclear waste lawsuit.

text.p: U.S. Energy Secretary Federico Pena said Wednesday he hoped to hold a meeting within about two weeks with utilities and other plaintiffs in a lawsuit against his department over its obligation to store nuclear power reactor waste.

Pena, speaking to reporters after a House Energy and Water Appropriations Subcommittee hearing, also said he wanted to be ready to start discussing the government's options since it will not have a storage facility ready to accept the spent nuclear fuel by the January 31, 1998, deadline.
"I want to hopefully be in a position to begin to discuss options on how to address the litigation and the obligations we have," Pena said.
Pena said "the general attitude" was to meet with parties and plaintiffs to the lawsuit filed by utilities, states and local commissions.
"I want this to be a working meeting where we can have a direct discussion on the litigation," he said, adding that he did not know if lawyers would have to be involved.
The department, under a 1982 law, is obliged to take responsibility for the radioactive waste next year.

Utilities, which generally are storing the waste onsite, have paid some $12 billion into a fund for the department to build a central storage facility, but the department still is assessing the viability of the one site in Nevada under consideration as a storage site. That site is not expected to be ready before 2010 or 2015.
"That looming court decision isn't going to go away," Pena said after courts last year agreed with the utilities that the department assumes responsibility for the waste on January 31.
Pena said the department has started reviewing suggestions that utilities submitted on how to deal with the waste issue.

"I know some have just taken the position that this is not our responsiblity. Thank you for giving us a chance to submit written comments, but this is your problem. But others apparently have made some effort to look at it," Pena said.

The Senate after recess is to take up a bill that would build a temporary waste dump to start accepting waste more quickly, but the Clinton administration has threatened to veto that because it says the measure would drain resources from building a permanent dump.
